title.narrative: Reducing Risk to Localized Food and WASH Emergency in Manicaland

description.narrative: The program is improving access to water and sanitation facilities and improving household food security through conservation farming and communal gardens. The program also enables behavior change related to hygiene. Mercy Corps is working in partnership with community based structures to promote transformative hygiene campaigns and provide incentives to rehabilitate water and sanitation infrastructure. The program is establishing 6720 ideal homesteads (homes that have clearly demarcated and established pot racks, refuse pits, hand washing and sanitation facilities) with 266 household and community water sources including 10 rain water harvesters. To promote demand for sanitation, 60 latrine builders are being trained through the construction of 240 latrines for extremely vulnerable households. To reduce food insecurity the program will build local capacity and promote the adoption of conservation farming to complement ongoing food distributions. While food aid is a short-term measure, Mercy Corps' program is improving food security through improved agricultural extension services introduce sustainable soil management practices, and training 2700 farmers on methods for nutrition and dietary diversity. By enabling farmers to adopt more productive and environmentally sustainable farming systems, intensification of vegetable gardening through 45 communal gardens and integrating training with access to water, farmers will extend food production to the dry season and generate household income. Improving household food security and sustaining behavior change around safe water and hygiene practices along with key infrastructure at the household and community level is integral to mitigating the continuous threat of a localized emergency.
